parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Altering pesticide application strategies can benefit natural enemies.
[Statement 2]: One controlled study reported more natural enemies when insecticides were sprayed earlier in the growing season.
[Statement 3]: Two trials found more natural enemies when herbicide treatments were delayed.
[Statement 4]: One study found that delaying herbicide treatments benefited some but not all natural enemy groups.
[Statement 5]: One study found that threshold-based spraying regimes increased numbers of natural enemies in two of three years.
[Statement 6]: One study found lower yields when herbicide treatments were delayed.
[Statement 7]: One study found no effect on yield when herbicide treatments were delayed.
[Statement 8]: Two studies found mixed effects on yield when insecticides were applied early.
[Statement 9]: One study found no effect on yield when insecticides were applied early.
[Statement 10]: One study found higher yields when insecticides were applied at times of suspected crop susceptibility.
[Statement 11]: Two studies found similar yields under threshold-based and conventional spraying regimes.
[Statement 12]: Two studies found that threshold-based spraying regimes had mixed effects on yields depending on site, year, pest stage/type or control treatment.
[Statement 13]: One study found higher profits when insecticides were only applied at times of suspected crop susceptibility.
[Statement 14]: One study found similar costs when insecticides were only applied at times of suspected crop susceptibility.
[Statement 15]: Nine studies found fewer pesticide applications were needed when using pesticides only when pests or crop damage reach threshold levels.
[Statement 16]: Three studies found or predicted lower production costs when using pesticides only when pests or crop damage reach threshold levels.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the overall effects of altering pesticide application strategies to benefit natural enemies?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Four studies found that growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies led to a higher number of natural enemies.
[Statement 2]: Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies led to a decrease in pest population or damage.
[Statement 3]: One study found an increase in crop yield from growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies.
[Statement 4]: A literature review found that planting new hedges resulted in lower pest outbreaks.
[Statement 5]: Two studies found that newly planted hedges had a higher abundance and diversity of beetles or spiders than crop fields or field margins.
[Statement 6]: One study found that planting new hedges had no effect on spiders in crops.
[Statement 7]: Another study found that the effect of new hedges on natural enemies varied between crop types, hedge species, and years.
[Statement 8]: The type of plant used in a hedge can affect arthropod diversity.
[Statement 9]: The type of plant used in a hedge can affect natural enemy abundance.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__When planting non-crop vegetation to enhance natural pest control, what is the comparative evidence for planting new hedges versus plants that attract natural enemies with chemicals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Crop growth was inhibited by allelopathic plant remains.
[Statement 2]: The inhibition of crop growth by allelopathic plant remains could be minimized by changing the timing of the application.
[Statement 3]: One study found negative effects on yield when amended plots were compared with weeded controls.
[Statement 4]: The crops studied included beans, cotton, maize, rice, and wheat.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the potential negative impacts on crops when incorporating plant remains into the soil to control weeds?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: One method of weed control is to incorporate plant remains into the soil that produce weed-controlling chemicals.
[Statement 2]: Incorporating plant remains into the soil that produce weed-controlling chemicals can reduce weed growth.
[Statement 3]: The effects of incorporating plant remains into the soil can vary and may not be long-lasting.
[Statement 4]: The impact of incorporating plant remains on crop growth, yield, and profit is variable when compared to both weeded and unweeded control plots.
[Statement 5]: In conservation areas, specific management regimes can reduce the abundance of pernicious weeds.
[Statement 6]: Cutting is a method for controlling creeping thistle.
[Statement 7]: Fungal pathogens can be used to control creeping thistle.
[Statement 8]: Lenient grazing can be used for long-term control of creeping thistle.
[Statement 9]: Weevils can be used to introduce systemic rust to control creeping thistle.
[Statement 10]: Hebridean sheep have been found to graze more purple moor grass than Swaledale sheep.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What actions can be taken to control weeds on farmland without relying on herbicides?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Leaving part of a crop unharvested was found to increase the number of predators in the unharvested area.
[Statement 2]: Leaving part of a crop unharvested was found to increase predator numbers in the wider field.
[Statement 3]: The ratio of predators to pests was higher in partially cut plots.
[Statement 4]: Creating beetle banks increased predator numbers in adjacent crops.
[Statement 5]: More invertebrate predators were found on beetle banks than in surrounding crops.
[Statement 6]: Beetle banks could lead to economic savings if pest numbers were kept below a spray threshold.
[Statement 7]: When leaving part of a crop unharvested, an increase in predation was found.
[Statement 8]: When leaving part of a crop unharvested, an increase in pest numbers in uncut areas was found.
[Statement 9]: When creating beetle banks, beetle activity in fields was greater.
[Statement 10]: The greater beetle activity in fields did not translate to increased pest predation.
[Statement 11]: Any movement of predators from beetle banks to the crops was small or slow.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__To provide refuge for natural enemies, what is the comparative evidence for creating beetle banks versus leaving part of a crop unharvested?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: One study on organic farming found that net profit increased if produce received a premium.
[Statement 2]: One study on organic farming found that profit decreased if produce did not receive a premium.
[Statement 3]: Another study on organic farming found a negative or no effect on profit.
[Statement 4]: In the context of alley cropping, one study found lower costs in alley cropped plots.
[Statement 5]: One study found lower profit in alley cropped plots.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the potential economic outcomes of adopting organic farming or alley cropping systems?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A replicated, controlled study from Australia found that leaving part of a crop or pasture unharvested or uncut led to an increase in predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs in the unharvested strips.
[Statement 2]: In one of two replicated, controlled studies from Japan and the USA, excluding ants that protect pests was found to increase parasitism of pests by natural enemies.
[Statement 3]: A separate replicated, controlled study from Japan or the USA showed mixed results when excluding ants that protect pests, with greater parasitism at one site but no effect at another.
[Statement 4]: A study in New Zealand on tomatoes found that using parasitism rates to inform spraying decisions resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Which interventions are most effective for increasing pest parasitism rates?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two studies, one of which was from the UK, found mixed results on natural enemy populations when grazing was used instead of cutting for pasture management.
[Statement 2]: One study from the UK that looked at the impact of delaying mowing found a decrease in the number of predatory spiders.
[Statement 3]: Three other studies from the UK reported no alteration in the number of insect predators.
[Statement 4]: Some studies have shown that delaying mowing can lead to an increase in the abundance of certain spiders and ground beetles.
[Statement 5]: Other studies have found no discernible impact on the communities of ground beetles or the prevalence of some insects and spiders from delaying mowing.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__For pasture management in the UK, what is the comparative evidence on natural enemy abundance when delaying mowing versus using grazing instead of cutting?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The use of alley cropping has been found to have mixed effects on parasitism, pests, and fungal infections.
[Statement 2]: A decrease in egg predation has been noted with the use of alley cropping.
[Statement 3]: In alley-cropped areas, there is an increase in wasps and spiders.
[Statement 4]: In alley-cropped areas, there is a decrease in ladybirds.
[Statement 5]: Some studies have reported a higher number of pests and more crop damage in alley-cropped areas.
[Statement 6]: Other studies have found opposite or varied effects on the number of pests and crop damage in alley-cropped areas.
[Statement 7]: Yields in alley-cropped areas were either lower or similar to conventional fields.
[Statement 8]: Despite lower costs in alley-cropped areas, profits were also reduced.
[Statement 9]: Newly planted hedges can support a greater abundance and variety of beetles and spiders compared to crop fields.
[Statement 10]: New hedges accommodate more ground beetles than older hedges.
[Statement 11]: A review of existing literature suggests that areas with new hedges experience fewer pest outbreaks.
[Statement 12]: One study did not find any impact on spider populations in crops from nearby hedges.
[Statement 13]: Another study indicated that the number of natural enemies in hedges could be greater than in the nearby crops.
[Statement 14]: The effect of hedges on natural enemies can vary based on the type of crop and hedge.
[Statement 15]: The type of plant used for a hedge has an impact on the number of natural enemies.
[Statement 16]: One study revealed that the effects of hedges on nematodes differed between groups of nematodes.
[Statement 17]: Hedges serve as corridors for the movement of invertebrates.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence for the effectiveness of manipulating field structure by adding linear features like hedges, beetle banks, or alley cropping?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Five studies compared natural and bare ground covers and the effects of those covers on natural enemies in fruit tree or vine canopies.
[Statement 2]: Three studies on ground covers found that the effects on natural enemies in canopies varied between different groups of natural enemies.
[Statement 3]: Two studies on ground covers found no difference in the effects on natural enemies in canopies.
[Statement 4]: Two additional studies compared natural to sown ground cover and found no effect on enemies in crop canopies.
[Statement 5]: When looking at natural enemies on the ground, five studies compared natural and bare ground covers.
[Statement 6]: Two of these studies found more natural enemies in the natural ground cover.
[Statement 7]: In one study, the effects of natural ground cover on natural enemies were only short-term for most natural enemy groups.
[Statement 8]: Three other studies found mixed effects, with higher numbers of some natural enemy groups but not others.
[Statement 9]: In a comparison of natural and sown ground covers, one study found more natural enemies in the natural cover.
[Statement 10]: In a comparison of natural and sown ground covers, one study found no effect on the number of natural enemies.
[Statement 11]: One replicated, controlled study in Australia on cashew trees found that predatory ants occupied more trees when the ant colonies were kept isolated.
[Statement 12]: The same study on cashew trees also found lower pest damage and higher yields when ant colonies were kept isolated.
[Statement 13]: One of two replicated, controlled studies found greater parasitism of pests by natural enemies when ants were excluded from trees.
[Statement 14]: Five other studies found that the effects of excluding ants on natural enemies in the tree canopy varied between species, sampling dates, sites, crop varieties, and ground cover types.
[Statement 15]: The crops studied included apple, grape, lemon, olive, pear, cashew, cherimoyas, cherry, grapefruit, orange, pecan, and satsuma mandarin.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What actions are available to a farmer growing perennial crops to enhance natural enemy populations on the ground versus in the tree canopy?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Nine studies in Australia, Slovakia, the UK, and the USA discovered that planting species to compete with weeds reduced weed plant weight or ground cover.
[Statement 2]: Five of these studies also discovered that competition reduced weed reproduction, survival, or both.
[Statement 3]: One study in the USA on emergent non-woody vegetation planted in freshwater wetlands discovered that removing an invasive species with herbicide before sowing mixed grass and forb seeds increased the total biomass of sown species after 1–2 growing seasons.
[Statement 4]: A study in the USA found that burning to remove an invasive species had no significant effect on the biomass of sown species.
[Statement 5]: Two studies in the United States that looked at the effect of weeding to remove competitors on the survival of planted sedges discovered that weeding had no significant effect on sedge survival in at least two of three years.
[Statement 6]: In six studies across Asia, Europe, and North America looking at allelopathic plant remains, three studies found a reduction in weed growth.
[Statement 7]: In six studies across Asia, Europe, and North America looking at allelopathic plant remains, three studies found that the effects varied between years, weed groups, or the type of weeding method in controls.
[Statement 8]: Two studies discovered that the decrease in weeds from allelopathic residue did not last more than a few days or weeks after the residue was incorporated.
[Statement 9]: One study in the United Kingdom discovered that hydrogen peroxide did not control Crassula helmsii.
[Statement 10]: One study in Taiwan discovered that stopping the use of pesticides, along with managing the habitat, led to an increase in the population of Taipei frogs.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the overall effects of weed management strategies that rely on plant competition or chemical properties?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Four studies on growing non-crop plants that produce attractive chemicals found a decrease in pest populations or damage.
[Statement 2]: Three studies on growing non-crop plants that produce attractive chemicals reported higher numbers of natural enemies.
[Statement 3]: The use of manufactured attractive chemicals showed more varied results.
[Statement 4]: For manufactured chemicals, five out of thirteen studies found an increase in natural enemies.
[Statement 5]: Eight studies on manufactured chemicals found that positive effects varied between enemy groups, sites or study dates.
[Statement 6]: Three of nine studies on manufactured chemicals found fewer pests.
[Statement 7]: Two studies on manufactured chemicals found more pests.
[Statement 8]: Four studies on manufactured chemicals found no effect on pests.
[Statement 9]: One study on non-crop plants that produce attractive chemicals found an increase in crop yield.
[Statement 10]: One study on manufactured chemicals found an increase in wheat yields.
[Statement 11]: The action of planting flowers to regulate pests showed mixed results.
[Statement 12]: Three replicated studies on planting flowers found greater pest reduction or higher proportions of parasitized pests.
[Statement 13]: One study found more pests on tomatoes next to planted flower strips.
[Statement 14]: One study found more aphids in fields after flower strips were made available.
[Statement 15]: Two studies found that some flower species were more attractive to natural enemies than other flower species.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__To attract natural enemies for pest control, what is the comparative evidence for using manufactured chemicals versus planting non-crop plants that produce attractive chemicals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Altering the timing of insecticide use has shown mixed effects on crop yield.
[Statement 2]: Two out of four studies on insecticide timing indicated varied outcomes on crop yield.
[Statement 3]: One study on insecticide timing reported no change in crop yield.
[Statement 4]: One study found higher crop yields when insecticides were applied during periods of anticipated crop vulnerability.
[Statement 5]: When pesticides are used only after pest or crop damage reaches a certain threshold, two out of four studies found yields to be comparable to conventional spraying methods.
[Statement 6]: Two studies noted that using pesticides only after pest or crop damage reaches a certain threshold resulted in mixed results for crop yields, depending on factors like location, year, and pest type.
[Statement 7]: A study on isolating beneficial ant colonies reported an increase in cashew yields.
[Statement 8]: One study found that delaying herbicide application resulted in lower crop yields.
[Statement 9]: In another study, delaying herbicide application had no effect on crop yields.
[Statement 10]: Push-pull cropping systems combine trap and repellent crops.
[Statement 11]: The use of push-pull cropping systems was found to increase crop yields in four out of five studies.
[Statement 12]: The impact of altering the timing of agricultural practices on pests and the pests' natural enemies also varies.
[Statement 13]: Earlier insecticide application was linked to a higher presence of natural enemies.
[Statement 14]: In two of four studies, earlier insecticide application led to a reduction in pests or disease-related damage.
[Statement 15]: Threshold-based pesticide use was found to boost the populations of natural enemies in two out of three years.
[Statement 16]: The boosting effects of threshold-based pesticide use on natural enemy populations were sometimes short-lived.
[Statement 17]: Isolating beneficial ant colonies led to more trees being occupied by the predatory ants.
[Statement 18]: Isolating beneficial ant colonies led to a decrease in pest-related damage.
[Statement 19]: Delayed herbicide use was associated with an increase in natural enemies.
[Statement 20]: Delayed herbicide use was also associated with more weeds.
[Statement 21]: Push-pull systems were found to have more natural predators.
[Statement 22]: Push-pull systems were found to have increased parasitism of stem borer larvae.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented effects on crop yield when altering the timing of agricultural practices like spraying or mowing for natural pest control?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence from North America for using natural or ecological methods to control weeds?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In North America, there are multiple ecological methods for weed control.
[Statement 2]: Two out of four studies in Asia and North America showed that incorporating plant remains with weed-controlling chemicals into the soil reduced weed growth compared to unweeded controls.
[Statement 3]: Two studies in the USA found that mixed pastures had fewer weeds than monoculture pastures.
[Statement 4]: In the USA, one study on organic farming found mixed results on weed seed predation by natural enemies.
[Statement 5]: Three studies on organic farming in the USA found more weeds in organic fields.
[Statement 6]: One study on organic farming noted that the effect on weeds varied by crop and year.
[Statement 7]: Another study on organic farming found no effect on the number of weeds.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the summary of evidence on the economic outcomes, such as profit and costs, of implementing natural pest control methods?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Using threshold-based spraying regimes resulted in similar profits to conventional spraying regimes.
[Statement 2]: One study noted that the effects of threshold-based spraying regimes varied between sites and years.
[Statement 3]: Push-pull cropping systems provided greater economic benefits.
[Statement 4]: Threshold-based spraying led to fewer pesticide applications.
[Statement 5]: Three studies reported or predicted that threshold-based spraying resulted in lower production costs.
[Statement 6]: One study on push-pull systems found higher production costs in the first year.
[Statement 7]: The production costs of push-pull systems were equal to or lower than conventional systems in the subsequent five years.
[Statement 8]: Beetle banks could lead to economic savings if the beetle banks effectively prevent pests from reaching a spray threshold.
[Statement 9]: Beetle banks could lead to economic savings if the beetle banks effectively prevent pests from causing a 5% loss in yield.

[Statement 1]: One review and two out of five studies found that attractive chemicals increased parasitism.
[Statement 2]: Two studies showed the effects of attractive chemicals varied based on chemicals, crops, or other factors.
[Statement 3]: Five of thirteen studies reported an increase in natural enemy populations.
[Statement 4]: Eight studies indicated that the positive effects on natural enemy populations varied among different enemy groups and study conditions.
[Statement 5]: The impact of attractive chemicals on pests was inconsistent.
[Statement 6]: Three of nine studies observed fewer pests.
[Statement 7]: Two of nine studies found an increase in pests.
[Statement 8]: Four of nine studies reported no effect on pests.
[Statement 9]: Three out of four studies noted higher numbers of natural enemies in plots with plants that produce attractive chemicals.
[Statement 10]: All four studies on plant-based attractants found a decrease in either pest population or crop damage.
[Statement 11]: One study on plant-based attractants reported an increase in crop yield.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the observed effects of using chemical or plant-based attractants to enhance natural enemy populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Delaying herbicide treatments may lead to an increase in natural enemies.
[Statement 2]: Delaying herbicide treatments can result in an increase in weeds.
[Statement 3]: The effects of delaying herbicide treatments on insect pests are inconsistent.
[Statement 4]: One study noted an increase in some pest groups from delaying herbicide treatments.
[Statement 5]: Another study found a decrease in certain pest groups in certain contexts from delaying herbicide treatments.
[Statement 6]: Yield outcomes from delaying herbicide use are varied.
[Statement 7]: One study reported lower yields from delaying herbicide use.
[Statement 8]: Another study on delaying herbicide use found no effect on yield.
[Statement 9]: The crops studied in relation to delaying herbicide use were beet and oilseed.
[Statement 10]: Altering the timing of insecticide use has shown different effects.
[Statement 11]: One study found that applying insecticides earlier in the season resulted in more natural enemies.
[Statement 12]: Early applications of insecticides led to fewer pests in two out of four studies.
[Statement 13]: Two studies showed that early insecticide applications had no effect on pests.
[Statement 14]: The impact on yield from changing insecticide timing is mixed.
[Statement 15]: One study found no effect on yield from the early application of insecticides.
[Statement 16]: One study noted higher yields when insecticide applications were timed to coincide with crop susceptibility.
[Statement 17]: One study indicated that applying insecticides only at times of suspected crop susceptibility could lead to higher profits with similar costs.
[Statement 18]: The crops studied for altering the timing of insecticide use included aubergine, barley, maize, pear, and stringbean.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__When altering the timing of chemical applications for pest control, what are the comparative effects of delaying herbicide use versus changing insecticide timing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several studies have documented the financial impacts of various natural pest control strategies, primarily focusing on crop yield.
[Statement 2]: The use of crop rotations has been found to result in higher crop yields in some instances when compared to monocultures.
[Statement 3]: Adding compost to the soil has led to higher crop yields in some comparisons.
[Statement 4]: In one case, adding compost to the soil led to fewer dead tomato plants.
[Statement 5]: The addition of pig slurry to the soil has been associated with higher crop yields in some studies.
[Statement 6]: The effects of some natural pest control strategies have been varied.
[Statement 7]: Planting flowers has been shown to increase crop yields in certain situations.
[Statement 8]: Planting flowers has been shown to lead to greater pest reduction.
[Statement 9]: Planting flowers has also been linked to increased pest numbers and crop damage in other cases.
[Statement 10]: Planting flowers was linked to smaller lettuces in one study.
[Statement 11]: The use of organic fertilizer has an inconsistent effect on yields.
[Statement 12]: Some studies on organic fertilizer report higher, lower, or similar yields compared to inorganic fertilizers.
[Statement 13]: Different tillage practices also show mixed results on crop yields.
[Statement 14]: Reduced tillage has been found to lead to higher, lower, or similar yields depending on the type of crop.
[Statement 15]: Studies on no-tillage systems have reported a range of outcomes, with yields being higher, lower, or the same as conventional tillage depending on the specific circumstances.
[Statement 16]: The use of ground cover has shown variable results.
[Statement 17]: Allowing natural ground cover to regenerate can have mixed effects on pest populations.
[Statement 18]: Planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards and vineyards has been found to decrease grape and avocado yields in some studies.
[Statement 19]: Planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards and vineyards has been found to increase chestnut and mushroom yields in other studies.
[Statement 20]: Growing cover crops in arable fields has been found to result in lower, inconsistent, or no difference in cash crop yields in a number of studies.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented financial impacts, in terms of profit and costs, of implementing various natural pest control strategies?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Utilizing mixed pasture instead of monoculture has been found to reduce weeds.
[Statement 2]: In conservation areas, the application of grass-specific herbicides has been shown to decrease grass diversity.
[Statement 3]: In conservation areas, the application of grass-specific herbicides has been shown to promote the growth of broadleaved plants.
[Statement 4]: Cutting is a method for controlling creeping thistle.
[Statement 5]: Introducing fungal pathogens is a method for controlling creeping thistle.
[Statement 6]: Implementing lenient grazing strategies is a method for controlling creeping thistle.
[Statement 7]: Weevils can be employed to infect creeping thistle with systemic rust.
[Statement 8]: In prairie restoration efforts, seeding with native species has been used.
[Statement 9]: In prairie restoration efforts, mowing has been used.
[Statement 10]: In prairie restoration efforts, weeding or applying herbicides has been used.
[Statement 11]: Hebridean sheep tended to graze more on purple moor grass compared to Swaledale sheep.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What actions are available to control weeds specifically in pasture or grassland systems?
